user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of call_connection_handler:
```c
static void
call_connection_handler (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  size_t processed;

  if (NULL != connection->rp.response)
    return;                     /* already queued a response */
  processed = 0;
  connection->rq.client_aware = true;
  connection->in_access_handler = true;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context))
  {
    connection->in_access_handler = false;
    /* serious internal error, close connection */
    CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR (connection,
                            _ ("Application reported internal error, " \
                               "closing connection."));
    return;
  }
  connection->in_access_handler = false;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
connection->rq.version
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: This code fragment (accessing connection->rq.version) does not itself call any <string.h> functions, so by itself it does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A violation could occur in a realistic scenario if the pointer stored in connection->rq.version is invalid or not a properly terminated character string and the called default_handler (or code it calls) uses <string.h> functions on it. For example, if connection->rq.version points to a non-null-terminated buffer or to memory beyond its allocated bounds and default_handler calls strlen(connection->rq.version) or strcpy/strncpy/strcat/etc., those library calls could read or write past the object bounds and thus violate Rule 21.17.
